title: Rita Ora turns heads in tiger-print boxing shorts as she arrives for another day of filming Twist
text:
She's landed another big screen role in the anticipated modern remake of Oliver!

And Rita Ora, 28, made a starry entrance for her day on set on Wednesday, arriving for filming in a typically quirky look alongside leading man Rafferty Law.

The singer turned actress teamed a pair of satin boxer shorts with plenty of layers to keep warm during her day of shooting Twist on the streets of London,.

Filming in style: Rita Ora made a starry entrance for another day filming the modern remake of Oliver! on Wednesday, alongside leading man Rafferty Law (right)

Rita, who is playing the Artful Dodger in Twist, sported a bright blue pair of satin boxing shorts, embellished with a tiger and star design.

She teamed the shorts with a red and blue striped top, fishnets and black leather lace-up knee-high boots.

Rita added to her look with two coats, layering a padded black number over a leather trench coat.

Quirky: The singer turned actress teamed a pair of satin boxer shorts with plenty of layers to keep warm during her day of shooting Twist on the streets of London

Feeling the hill: The finishing touches were a Burberry shawl and a quirky aviator hat, complete with ear flaps to keep her extra warm

The finishing touches were a Burberry shawl and a quirky aviator hat, complete with ear flaps to keep her extra warm.

The star carried a take out coffee and wrapped her shawl around her as she prepared to start shooting.

Rafferty meanwhile was in a more simple look, dressed in a white t-shirt under his black padded jacket, while keeping comfy inbetween takes in a pair of fluffy slippers.

It's fashion: Rita added leather fingerloss gloves to her look and clutched her phone as she walked around the set

Big screen role: The star carried a take out coffee and wrapped her shawl around her as she prepared to start shooting

Star: Rafferty meanwhile was in a more simple look, dressed in a white t-shirt under his black padded jacket, while keeping comfy inbetween takes in a pair of fluffy slippers

Rita and Rafferty have been busy shooting Twist all week, with MailOnline revealing days before the shoot started that the son of Jude Law had landed the lead role in the re-imagining of Charles Dickens' enduring classic.

With Rita cast as the Artful Dodger, comedian David Walliams, 48, will play Losberne and Sir Michael Caine, 86, takes on the iconic role of Fagin.

A source close to the project said: 'Shooting for the new film starts today and everyone is very excited to get started.

Big break: Rita and Rafferty have been busy shooting Twist all week, with MailOnline revealing days before the shoot started that the son of Jude Law had landed the lead role

'Twist is a modern interpretation of Charles Dickens’ Oliver in which the title character has been reinvented as a streetwise artist living on the streets of modern-day London.

'Rafferty impressed with his screen presence and his edginess brings a whole new dimension to the role of Oliver.

'It’s an all-star cast with David in the mix after arriving at today's first rehearsal – not to mention Rita and Sir Michael Caine.'

All star cast: Sir Michael Caine was also seen on set on Wednesday, dressed for his role as the story's villain, Fagin

In the new film, Oliver and Dodger get caught up in a heist to steal a priceless painting for master thief, Fagin.

On playing the villain, Sir Michael Caine said: 'Fagin is such an infamous character, it’s going to be great fun playing him.

'I’m really looking forward to working with Lena, Raff and the rest of the cast in London when we start shooting.'

New plot: In the new film, Oliver and Dodger get caught up in a heist to steal a priceless painting for master thief, Fagin

Game Of Thrones star Lena Headey plays Sikes, who's been described as 'Fagin's psychopathic business partner,' in the original film directed by Martin Owen.

Rafferty added: 'I’m excited to play such a well-loved literary character.

'I’m looking forward to working with Martin Owen to bring to life his new take on the character in modern-day London.'
